head.title: Black, White, Gray: America Talks About Race; The Quarterback

hedline.hl1: Black, White, Gray: America Talks About Race; The Quarterback

abstract.p: Saman Jayasinghe letter on July 2 article about white quarterback at black college; recalls growing up in Louisiana, as Marcus Jacoby did, but as South Asian

block.p: Like Marcus Jacoby, I went to high school in Baton Rouge, La. (''The Minority Quarterback,'' ''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, July 2). As a person of South Asian descent, I prided myself in my ability to interact comfortably with both blacks and whites alike. At first, I assumed that it was my ''neutral'' race that enabled me to be accepted by both groups, but it was not until I spent a semester in Spain in my college years that I realized my real advantage was not in my brown color but in my ability to mix comfortably with people of different cultures.

Like Marcus Jacoby, I went to high school in Baton Rouge, La. (''The Minority Quarterback,'' ''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, July 2). As a person of South Asian descent, I prided myself in my ability to interact comfortably with both blacks and whites alike. At first, I assumed that it was my ''neutral'' race that enabled me to be accepted by both groups, but it was not until I spent a semester in Spain in my college years that I realized my real advantage was not in my brown color but in my ability to mix comfortably with people of different cultures.

Although there is no doubt that racism made it difficult for Marcus Jacoby to adjust to life at Southern University, it is the everyday problem of being in a place where you are culturally different that makes life the most strenuous.
SAMAN JAYASINGHE Baton Rouge, La., July 2, 2000
